726231f-a.title: Queens: Broadway - Queens Boulevard
726231f-a.text:
Broadway (police thereon), north from Queens Boulevard, showing
at the left on the N.W. corner the Heeg Hotel erected by John Heeg
in 1891. This structure was partially demolished in October 1930.
Portions of it, however, still remain.
March 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727704f-a.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - Broadway
727704f-a.text:
Queens Boulevard, north side, west of Broadway to Van Loon
Street. Eugene L. Armbruster states that the building in the fore-
ground was the original Baptist Church of Elmhurst and that it was
erected in 1809. This structure originally stood on the damaica
Road, south side, east of Horse Brook Road, and was moved to Grand
Street in 1857 and remodeled (opposite Town Hallf) and from the last
location was moved to the present site.
January 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727705f.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - Broadway
727705f.text:
Queens Boulevard (foreground), north side, at Broadway (center),
showing at the N.W. corner of same, the Heeg Hotel, erected by John

Heeg in i89i. This structure, partially demolished in October 1930,
.still remains in part today (1938). Through the center appears a

northward view on Broadway, which curves westward from this point,
and upon which runs the newly constructed Independent Subway.(15340
'44
k ~4
March 1923.

726756f-a.folder: Grand Avenue & Queens Boulevard, Queens, NY

727709f-a.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - Grand Avenue
727709f-a.text:
Quueens Poulevard at the S.E. corner of Grand Avenue, show-
ino the corner houe. IIt was erected about 1716 by Jorathan
Fish who kent a tavern. Hie died in 1723. His son Samuel
conducted it urtil he died 1767. Abraham Rapelye operated it
during the Revolutionary War. At this time it as also the
headquarters of the Lovalists. After the war it was called the
Vnion Hotel. On May 3, 1817 it was pu'chased by the town for
tbe Preshvterian Parsonage for the Rev. Wm. Boardman and bsed
as such until 1822 whenn the 3rd parsonage vas erected.
Rev. Boardman died 1818 and was succeeded by the Rev. John
Goldsmith D.D. The house was sold in 1822 and was used first
as a store and then for many years as a residence. It stood
vacant for years and was fiallv taken down. Thia site was
origirally occupied by the hose of Ralph Hunt. Peter Duryea
was the ouner in 1852.
Nugene L. Armbruster Collectionn
